captions.text:
Good morning, Hank. It's Tuesday. I have a
flu-like illness, so you should prepare yourself

for the worst vlogbrothers video ever. To
make it slightly more entertaining, I'm gonna

play some Project for Awesome livestream highlights,
so you don't have to look at my sick mug.

So, Hank, this whole thing started while Henry
was giving me Sharpie face on Saturday morning

during the Project for Awesome, and I felt
a little tickle in my throat. I thought it

was Sharpie fumes, and, you know, maybe it
was, maybe Sharpies caused my illness. But,

at any rate, yeah, now I'm miserably ill,
which sucks, because there are only a few

days left in the Paper Towns shoot, and I
wanna be with those people because awesome

things are happening today in a minivan. But
I also don't wanna get them sick because they

still have to finish the movie.
More importantly, the Project for Awesome

has raised over $1.2 million for charity,
by far the most successful P4A of all time.

Nerdfighters, thanks to all of you who donated,
who made P4A videos, who watched them, and

shared them, and commented, and watched the
live show. I don't know what you guys thought

of this year's Project for Awesome -- I'm
interested to hear in comments, but for me

it was definitely the best one yet, at least
until I was stuck by this terrible Sharpie
illness.

John-from-livestream: Cover it with Sharpie,
yes!

Henry-from-livestream: No, I don't wanna cover
it.

John-from-livestream: Oh, you don't wanna
cover it.

Henry-from-livestream: If you cover it guess
what.

John-from-livestream: What?
Henry-from-livestream: You like... get forehead
disease.

Oh, Henry you were so right to be worried
about forehead diseases, which reminds me

to thank my family for their patience and
participation in this year's Project for Awesome,

not least Sarah, who allowed herself to be
covered in jelly. And I should also mention

that the Indiegogo is still live. You can
donate for the rest of today and today only,

to get amazing perks, from a calendar featuring
YouTubers before they were YouTubers, to the

Project for Awesome exclusive edition of The
Fault in Our Stars. There's also original

art by Minute Physics, An Imperial Affliction,
P4A socks, pressed pennies, and so much more.

Donations are tax-deductible in the US, and
all of your money after manufacturing costs

and shipping goes to charities that are chosen
by the Nerdfighter community at projectforawesome.com.

Ah, man, this reminds me of when #bananaeyes
trended on Twitter. Happier days, Hank, happier
days.

Sarah-from-livestream: Yay!
John-from-livestream: You look adorable. How

do I look?
Sarah-from-livestream: It's gross.

So Hank, the Foundation to Decrease Worldsuck
works because there's no overhead. Everyone

who packs and ships perks at the DFTBA Records
Warehouse volunteers their time, as does Sam

Rudge, who does the website work, Karen Kavett,
who designs it, Lauren Chernikoff, and dozens

of other people. So to everyone who was part
of this year's Project for Awesome, thank

you, thank you. We did it! $1 million! Actually
like 200,000 more than a million. Hank, here's

a sentence I thought I would never say: you
are the most beautiful mummy dancer the world
has ever known. I'll see you on Friday.

title: Jelly Face, Sharpie Face, Peanut Butter Face, and Mummy Dancers: The 2014 Project for Awesome

comments.author: Pragnya Patil

comments.text:
I have thought about this for a while and I believe this is almost right. 
Fame, wealth, success is all luck. If you are any of these you are the 
lucky .01% of the population of 'Murica. It doesn't matter if you work hard 
for something you love, either you get noticed by enough to sputter through 
life, live long enough to prosper, or fail miserably and become that guy on 
the street asking for spare change but no one will give it to you because 
they thing you're a drugalcoholic. But the lucky .01% are perfectly noticed 
by the right person and work hard at the right thing at the right time for 
their popularity to boom into an force that none can rival. Which makes me 
mad as hell. If I put 100 hours of work into something I love, sacrifice 
that time, shouldn't I get mor than a "No" or Good try but....", but a guy 
plays a game for 20 minutes edits it and puts it on YouTube get 5 million 
fans. Goddamit I have as good of a chance as anybody to become something 
that I want to be. I want to be that person that can get noticed by someone 
I have never met, I mean, don't we all. Fame, wealth, it is all an 
injustice to the Other.

﻿

comments.text:
In which a very sick +John Green discusses the 2014 Project for Awesome, 
which has raised more than $1,200,000 for charity. John also does peanut 
butter face with banana eyes while his heroic wife Sarah does jelly face, 
and then Hank is a dancing mummy. Learn more at http://projectforawesome.com

Thanks to Sarah for all her help this weekend. Check out her show with PBS 
Digital, The Art Assignment: http://www.youtube.com/theartassignment﻿

comments.author: patrikr

comments.text:
Hi John! First, just let me thank you for being the awesome person that you 
are! Not only do you write awesome, funny, (I can't remember the last time 
I laughed as hard as I did reading Paper Towns.“As far as I can tell, there 
are two basic (kissing) rules: 1. Don't bite anything without permission. 
2. The human tongue is like wasabi: it's very powerful, and should be used 
sparingly.” And like the whole page after that!) and (surprisingly) 
relatible books, but you are so down to earth. So thank you. You have 
inspired me to do what I love despite the lack of support I have. I love to 
write. Love it. And I am almost done with my first full length novel, 
although I have started ideas for like three others. The problem is, I 
don't know what to do next. Where do I send the story for publication, how 
many places should I send it to at first, what are some good publishers 
that would even consider publishing an unknown like me? Any tips would be 
great. Thank you in advance,- Julia.﻿
comments.author: Juliet Athena

comments.text:
John and Hank, I need to get through to talk to the two of you. I was 
planning on donating and selecting the Imperial Affliction prop for my 
girlfriend for Christmas, but the P4A campaign ended before I could 
finalize, and I want to somehow still make this happen. If you could reach 
out to me, I would be very thankful and forever beholden to you guys. I've 
been a long-time nerdfighter, and this is a really big deal to me (and 
Hannah, my girlfriend).﻿

I didn't really have the best day today but that made me smile recalling

was able to be a part of P4A. My best friend participated with me, which 
turned into silly and serious moments of our own.
Im so proud of this community and so proud to be a nerdfighter!
1.2 Million guys...That is a lot of money to really great causes.
Hope you feel better soon, John! 
DFTBA!
Merry Fartmas!
(Spell check tried to turn Nerdfighter into Fire Fighter's...when will my 
computer learn to be awesome?) ﻿

comments.text:
Dear John Green, I am writing this desperate comment on his youtube account 
hoping to do some ecepsión ... I do not know him personally but without 
knowing I suppose it's a beautiful person. Maybe not read this comment or 
not even relevant to any of these comments, but I can not stand the urge to 
talk with you and share with my literary thoughts, although I would stay in 
shame crossing just a word with the great John Green. I do not intend to go 
to meet him at his house in Indianapolis or that you, do answer me 
questions like Hazel, I have about his book. I only ask you to write me at 
my address, please, I ask him, I have a friend who is starting to write 
something and it's really good ... waiting for your answer please and eager 
to talk to you ... I'm in love of his book The Fault in Our Star.

Greatefull, his big fan, Gabriela.﻿

comments.author: nomainreason

comments.text:
I'm interested to know how much was raised during the first day/for 
predetermined charities and how much actually gets to go to those we voted 
on.  It's amazing that so much was raised so much, and I know it's all 
going to good causes, but somehow it just doesn't feel like it's the same 
accomplishment to raise a million for predetermined charities with half or 
more being matching donations as to actually raise 800,000 for mixed ones 
of the communities choosing without those matching donations.  I was 
unfortunately in the ER in the middle of the event, so I honestly have no 
even approximate idea what the amount was when the day changed over.﻿
